title: Wildfire danger in Eagle County is pretty low , thanks to a cool , moist spring
message:
Mitigation efforts over the past several years have helped reduce the risk of wildfire, but nothing helps keep fire danger at bay like a lot of snow and a cool, moist spring.
Birch Barron, the county’s emergency management director, on Tuesday updated the Eagle County Board of Commissioners on current wildfire conditions in the area.
But, he noted, no part of Eagle County was in any form of drought at the end of April, adding that the county was bordering on “abnormally dry” at the end of April in 2023.
That snow is coming off fairly slowly, again thanks to a reasonably cool spring so far.
The good news from the cooler spring conditions applies to spring runoff.

title: Texas and Louisiana flooding : Rare high risk of extreme rainfall to trigger  life - threatening  flooding
message:
CNN —A dangerous, life threatening flash flooding event is unfolding Thursday as torrential storms pound the already-soaked South.
A rare Level 4 of 4 high risk of excessive rainfall was issued for parts of eastern Texas and western Louisiana by the Weather Prediction Center Thursday.
A few spots caught under multiple torrential storms may pick up 8 inches or more of rain.
Texas and Louisiana have been in the bull’s-eye of seemingly unrelenting rounds of torrential, flooding downpours since the start of April.
Serious flash flooding is likely in any areas caught under multiple storms unloading 2 to 3 inches of rain per hour.

title: Flood - Prone Houston Faces a Deluge of More Rain : Weather Watch
message:

Flood watches have been posted from Dallas and Houston eastward across Louisiana and Mississippi.
Flood-prone Houston saw waters rising earlier this month, closing roads, affecting energy supplies and sending residents fleeing.

title: Oregon officials say 2024 fire season threat slightly less than 2023
message:
PORTLAND Ore. (KPTV) - The threat of wildfires in Oregon for summer 2024 should be less than last year, at least for the early summer months, state forestry experts said on Wednesday.
That’s according to experts with the state’s forestry department - who provided a look at what we can expect as wildfire season approaches.
Oregon saw a considerable amount of rain and snow throughout the winter months, building a strong snowpack.
Tina Kotek, said this could mean more complex and challenging wildfire conditions in the later summer months.
The Department of Forestry said it’s preparing for the season by making sure resources are in place to fight fires when they do start, including new modernized equipment.

title: Looming fires force thousands of Canadians to evacuate . Some may not return home until next week
message:
CNN —Colossal wildfires burning across Canada over the last week have driven thousands of people to evacuate with their kids, pets and precious belongings in tow – many uncertain when they may be able to return home.
More than 6,000 people have evacuated from Fort McMurray in Alberta since Tuesday as a 51,000 acre fire burns less than 5 miles from the city’s edge.
Flames and smoke fill the air as wildfires burn nearby in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada on May 2016.
Courtesy Jocelyn Routhier Flames and smoke fill the air as wildfires burn nearby in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada on May 14, 2024.

title: Army Corps prepares Lake Okeechobee ahead of  extremely active  hurricane season
message:
In February, the Corps implemented releases to the Caloosahatchee and St. Lucie Estuary to bring lake levels down ahead of the 2024 hurricane season, which is already forecasted to be “extremely active.”The plan worked.
As of Wednesday, May 15, 2024, Lake Okeechobee stands at 13.73 feet.
The 143-mile earthen dam system encircles Lake Okeechobee and is routinely inspected.
It reduces impacts from flooding as a result of high lake levels for a large area of south Florida.
On the cusp of this hurricane season, the Corps is prepared for it.

title: Canadian wildfires haze U . S . skies , trigger air quality warnings in multiple states
message:
Wildfire smoke has lowered air quality and made for some hazy skies in areas like Minneapolis and Kansas City this week.
The upper-level winds have shifted, which resulted in the smoke from these fires filtering into the United States.
On Tuesday, Code Orange (3 of 6) air quality was reported in cities like Topeka, Kansas.
The 2023 Canadian wildfire season was record-breaking with about 45 million acres burned, which is nearly two and a half times the previous record of 17.5 million acres burned in 1995.
While it is expected to be another busy wildfire season this year, it is also not expected to be anywhere near the activity and widespread as last year.

title: Fort Nelson , B . C ., wildfire expands to 127 sq km but cooler temps expected
message:
See more sharing optionsSend this page to someone via emailShare this item on TwitterShare this item via WhatsAppShare this item on FacebookBritish Columbia’s wildfire service says the blaze threatening the northern community of Fort Nelson now spans nearly 130 square kilometres, but it had spread away from the town along its southern flank.
The service says the Parker Lake fire has been mapped at 127 square kilometres in size, up from 84 square kilometres earlier this week.
It says cooler temperatures and higher relative humidity were expected to make for more favourable conditions over the next couple of days fighting the fire that was only two kilometres southwest of the town earlier this week.
Story continues below advertisementThere may be some light rain, but the BC Wildfire Service says it won’t be enough to “offset the prolonged drought and cause the fires to self-extinguish.”Breaking news from Canada and around the world sent to your email, as it happens.
Rob Fraser, the mayor of the Northern Rockies Regional Municipality, which includes Fort Nelson, told a community meeting that he now feels confident they will get word eventually that the fire is not threatening the community.

title: Local officials keeping eye on busy hurricane season forecast
message:
Predictions are calling for a busier than usual Atlantic storm season, and Liberty County officials have begun getting organized for a potentially active summer and fall.
Hurricane season begins June 1 and ends November 30.
Forecasters at Colorado State University are predicting an unusually active Atlantic hurricane season, with 23 named storms, 11 hurricanes and five major hurricanes.
Water temperatures in the eastern and central Atlantic are at record warm levels and are expected to remain well above average for the upcoming hurricane season.
CSU’s forecast team anticipates a well above-average probability for major hurricanes making landfall along the U.S. coast for the 2024 hurricane season.

title: Prepare for the Coming Storm Season at Port St . Lucie 2024 Hurricane Expo
message:
Port St. Lucie - Thursday May 16, 2024: Hurricane season is right around the corner, which makes now the perfect time to start preparing.
The 18th annual Hurricane Preparedness Expo will take place Saturday, June 1 from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at MIDFLORIDA Event Center, located at 9221 SE Event Center Place in Port St. Lucie.
This free, family-friendly event connects residents with businesses and emergency providers who can help them prepare for extreme weather situations.
This year’s Expo will feature informative presentations from meteorologists, emergency managers, City of Port St. Lucie staff and community organizations that can assist with hurricane preparations.
While supplies last, attendees will receive a tote bag with hurricane and preparedness information, and those who complete the scavenger hunt will receive a water bottle.

title: Haunting photos show a Six Flags in New Orleans that has been abandoned for almost 2 decades
message:
Almost two decades later, Six Flags New Orleans still sits abandoned, now a time capsule of life before Katrina.
Originally called Jazzland, it was acquired by Six Flags in 2003 and renamed Six Flags New Orleans (SFNO).
When another company made its interest in the land known, pitching the "Dreamlanding Festival Park," Mayor Landrieu didn't approve.
Gone was the scent of cotton candy and the sounds of laughter as I walked into the abandoned Six Flags Amusement Park.
As Biz New Orleans reported, the next step is raising $500 million to begin construction, and signing tenants.

title: Oregon prepares for above - average wildfire season amid firefighter staffing challenges
message:
Officials from the Oregon Department of Forestry and Oregon State Fire Marshal said Wednesday they expect an above-average wildfire season for July and August in eastern parts of the state.
"Just as we saw last weekend, temperatures are increasing in our state,” said Doug Grafe, wildfire adviser for Gov.
The Oregon Department of Forestry relies on more than 700 firefighters.
State Fire Marshal Mariana Ruiz-Temple said further complicating Oregon’s fire season is a dwindling pool of firefighters.
“On average, this investment brings about 1,600 firefighters, supports 1,600 firefighters during key fire season,” she said.

title: Two rainstorms heading for Ghana - GMet warns
message:
The Ghana Meteorological Agency (GMet) says its weather monitoring station has observed double rainstorms heading for the country on Thursday, May 16.
Areas within the coastal and northern sectors will be hit by heavy rainfall accompanied by strong winds and thundery conditions.
"A rainstorm that is moderately producing thunderstorms with rain over northern Benin into Togo is expected to drift further westwards to affect the northern half of Ghana.
However, a separate rainstorm observed over Nigeria is also expected to propagate westwards to affect the coastal and middle sectors of the country," the statement read.
The recent severe rainstorm left in its wake destruction in parts of Accra, as trees fell and damaged several cars.

title: Officials learn from the past in responding to this year Fort McMurray wildfire
message:
Josée St-Onge, a spokesperson for Alberta Wildfire, said until 11 p.m. on Wednesday there were still open flames stretching into the sky.
Another fire burning about three kilometres north of Fort McMurray is now classified as being held, which means it is not likely to spread beyond its current boundaries.
It is about one hectare in size and Alberta Wildfire said in its morning update that it poses no threat to the city.
More than 6,000 residents from four neighbourhoods are still under an evacuation order that was issued on Tuesday.
There were 42 active wildfires in Alberta, as of early Thursday, with the Fort McMurray inferno being the only one classified as out-of-control.

title: Cities look for new ways to keep people safe and alive as extreme summer heat looms
message:
“We prepare for heat year-round in Phoenix,” Mayor Kate Gallego said.
The 2023 heat waves revealed how challenging it can be to cope with extreme temperatures for weeks on end, even in places where residents are accustomed to warm weather.
That has prompted cities across the South and the Southwest to re-evaluate how best to keep people safe — and alive — this summer.
Gallego said Phoenix has been creating “cool corridors” by planting trees and resurfacing the pavement with more reflective coatings to reduce urban heat.
A primary focus right now is mitigating high overnight temperatures, which plagued the city last summer.

title: The US Navy only forward - deployed aircraft carrier , USS Ronald Reagan , is leaving Japan after nearly a decade in the Pacific
message:
After nearly a decade, the USS Ronald Reagan is leaving the Pacific.
USS Ronald Reagan has served in other roles, providing air support in Afghanistan and aiding Japan after its 2011 disaster.
The USS Ronald Reagan, the only aircraft carrier in the US Navy forward deployed, or permanently stationed in another country, is leaving Japan after spending nearly a decade in the Pacific.
USS Ronald Reagan traveling through the Straits of Magellan, to San Diego, CA, in a transfer move.
"Whether it's aboard USS Ronald Reagan today or USS George Washington in the future, we will continue to strengthen those ties at all levels, on-shore and at-sea."

message:

title: Oregon prepares for above - average wildfire season amid firefighter staffing challenges
message:
Officials from the Oregon Department of Forestry and Oregon State Fire Marshal said Wednesday they expect an above-average wildfire season for July and August in eastern parts of the state.
"Just as we saw last weekend, temperatures are increasing in our state,” said Doug Grafe, wildfire adviser for Gov.
The Oregon Department of Forestry relies on more than 700 firefighters.
State Fire Marshal Mariana Ruiz-Temple said further complicating Oregon’s fire season is a dwindling pool of firefighters.
“On average, this investment brings about 1,600 firefighters, supports 1,600 firefighters during key fire season,” she said.

Tonette Waltman Jackson's remains were identified in May 2024 — almost two decades after her death during Hurricane Katrina.
He added: "In 2005, when Jane Love or Tonette's remains were found, forensic genetic genealogy was not a tool that was available."

title: Is the death rate of Tahoe trees getting better or worse ?
message:
– California red fir mortality increased to approximately 1.6 million dead trees across 63,000 acres in 2023 from ~1.3 million dead trees across 54,000 acres in 2022.
– In 2023, white fir mortality decreased to 6 dead trees from an estimated 14,000 dead trees across 1,500 acres in 2022.
18- Tahoe National Forest– Mortality increased to an estimated 6.5 million dead trees across 330,000 acres in 2023 from ~5 million dead trees across 260,000 acres in 2022.
– California red fir mortality increased to approximately 6 million dead trees across 290,000 acres in 2023 from ~3.8 million dead trees across 170,000 acres in 2022.
– White fir mortality decreased to approximately 160,000 dead trees across 22,000 acres in 2023 from ~890,000 dead trees across 74,000 acres in 2022.

title: Less than a third of Iowa has drought
message:
(Courtesy of National Drought Mitigation Center)The state’s dryness has subsided to a level comparable with about a year ago, and less than a third of Iowa now has drought, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor.
A Thursday report — which is a snapshot of the conditions two days before — said about 27% of the state has some measure of drought.
Almost all of the remaining drought resides in the northeast quadrant of the state, and most of that drought is classified as “severe.”About 92% of the topsoil in farm fields has adequate or surplus moisture for growing crops, the USDA reported Monday.
Those totals might exceed two inches in parts of northern and eastern Iowa.

title: Cities look for new ways to keep people safe and alive as extreme summer heat looms
message:
Ward and her colleagues specialize in “heat governance,” helping local and state governments prepare for extreme heat events.
The work includes finding ways to mitigate heat and develop emergency responses for major heat waves.
Ward said that it’s heartening to see cities take extreme heat seriously but emphasized that major challenges lie ahead.
For one, preparing early for extreme heat requires funding, which is a major challenge, especially for rural communities.
Even trickier will be addressing the underlying social issues that get magnified during heat waves, such as homelessness, rising energy costs and economic inequality.

title: Climate change could force Bangkok to move , official warns
message:
Thailand's Deputy DG Department of Climate change and Environment Pavich Kesavawong.
— AFP/FileBANGKOK: Thailand may have to consider relocating its capital Bangkok because of rising sea levels, a senior official in the country’s climate change office said on Wednesday.
Projections consistently show that low-lying Bangkok risks being inundated by the ocean before the end of the century.
Pavich Kesavawong, deputy director-general of the government’s department of climate change and environment, warned that the city might not be able to adapt with the world on its current warming pathway.
Thailand is suffering the effects of climate change across a range of sectors, from farmers struggling with heat and drought to tourism businesses affected by coral bleaching and pollution.

title: Nepal JRAP receives £13 million boost from FCDO for earthquake recovery
message:
KATHMANDU, May 16: The Joint Recovery Action Plan (JRAP) for Western Nepal's earthquake-affected regions has received a significant financial boost from the UK's Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO).
The British Embassy in Kathmandu has announced a contribution of £13 million to aid the recovery efforts in the municipalities impacted by the February 2024 earthquake.
The new funding aims to support vulnerable communities through life-saving services, rebuilding livelihoods, and fostering long-term resilience.
The NDRRMA's Chief Executive, Anil Pokhrel, acknowledged FCDO's ongoing support, noting its importance for the reconstruction and recovery of Karnali Province.
The JRAP aims to complement Nepal’s ongoing recovery efforts, targeting a funding need of USD 96 million to assist 250,000 individuals, promoting resilient construction and local employment while reducing the carbon footprint.

title: Texas Governor Greg Abbott requests presidential disaster declaration following recent severe weather
message:
Texas Governor Greg Abbott has sent a letter to President Joe Biden requesting a Presidential Disaster Declaration for Texas communities that were impacted by recent weather and flooding that began last month.
The Governor's letter requests individual assistance programs for seven impacted counties and public assistance programs for 26 impacted counties.
"Due to severe weather and flooding that continues to cause devastating damage in several of our communities, I am requesting a Presidential Disaster Declaration," Abbott said in a statement.
This Presidential Disaster Declaration will give local communities across to critical financial assistance that will help cover costs ranging from temporary housing and home repairs to grant funding for roads and bridges.
I thank the Texas Division of Emergency Management for working with our local and federal partners to bolster Texas' recovery efforts across the state."

The data, gathered from 679 people in January and February, comes from what researchers hope will be a long-term study of wildfire survivors lasting at least a decade.
Many study participants had not seen a doctor, he said.
Some study participants said they were not able to because clinics had burned down or because they prioritised getting housing, jobs and food after the disaster.
Just pay more attention to your health because of this.”Two-thirds of study participants lived in Lahaina at the time of the fires.
About half of the participants reported daily or weekly exposure to smoke, ash or debris.

title: New report finds staggering number of Americans face  climate penalty  with concerning health implications :  Were essentially adding back additional premature deaths
message:
A quarter of Americans are now exposed to unhealthy air in what experts are calling a "climate penalty."
A report from the First Street Foundation found that one in four Americans faces unhealthy air, Grist reported.
What's more, using climate and wildfire models, the group estimated that by mid-century, half of Americans will experience at least one day of risky unhealthy air.
Ultimately, the World Health Organization says that around seven million people die prematurely due to air pollution — this works out to 13 people each minute, and children are most at risk.
"We're essentially adding back additional premature deaths, adding back additional heart attacks," Porter said, per Grist.

title: Hurricane Katrina victim identified nearly 2 decades after deadly storm
message:
Almost two decades after a woman's death during Hurricane Katrina, modern forensic tests finally allowed authorities to identify her remains.
Tonette Waltman Jackson's remains were identified in May 2024 — almost two decades after her death during Hurricane Katrina.
He added: "In 2005, when Jane Love or Tonette's remains were found, forensic genetic genealogy was not a tool that was available."
Earlier this month, testing on a DNA sample submitted by one of Jackson's close family members confirmed her identity.
Hardy Jackson gave an on-camera interview to CBS affiliate WKRG in the immediate aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and shared his wife's story.

title: Sunday Forecast : Storms in the High Plains
message:
16 May 2024 5:00 PMYet another severe weather chance is ahead for the central Plains with a large swath of Nebraska and Kansas highlighted by the Storm Prediction Center [SPC] on Sunday for the severe weather potential.
All modes of severe weather are possible as storms develop through the heat of the day.
May is the busiest month of the year for severe weather with most storms setting up over the Great Plains of Nebraska, Kansas, Oklahoma, and northern Texas.
Already 2024 has been one of the busiest severe weather seasons with the second most tornadoes on record (2011 still holds the record).
Stay with WeatherNation for the latest storm timing and threats ahead of the severe weather threat.

title: NWS issues flood watch for burn scars in northern New Mexico
message:
As we progress closer to monsoon season, there is one thing we are watching closely in northern New Mexico – burn scar flooding.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. – As we progress closer to monsoon season, there is one thing we are watching closely in northern New Mexico – burn scar flooding.
On Wednesday, we’ve seen some rain and thunderstorms pretty close to the burn scars.
It doesn’t take much for flooding to happen over our burn scars, either.
That is why the National Weather Service in Albuquerque has already put out a flood watch for the Calf Canyon/Hermits Peak burn scar and the McBride burn scar for Thursday.
